meta.content: COVID-19 Closure | Glendale School District | Glendale, Oregon | Glendale School District

meta.name: twitter:description
meta.content: Dear Glendale Families,We understand that this is a difficult time for our students and their families.  Our top priority right now remains the safety and

div.p: We understand that this is a difficult time for our students and their families. Our top priority right now remains the safety and health of our students and staff. We are also working closely with the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) as we work to support our graduating seniors, for our students return to school, and to provide continuity of learning to the fullest extent possible. We continue to look for additional guidance from ODE on how to equitably deliver instruction to all students during this extended closure.

As you have been made aware, due to the COVID-19 public health concerns, Governor Brown recently announced an extension of Oregon’s statewide school closure through April 28, 2020. Governor Brown’s Executive Order directs schools across the State of Oregon to:

li.p: Deliver supplemental education and learning supports to students, to the extent practical, through independent study and other appropriate options.
Provide meals for students during this closure.

Provide for supplemental services and emergency management services, including but not limited to, the provision of child care for first responders, emergency workers, health care professionals, and other individuals, consistent with any guidance and requirements provided by the Oregon Department of Education.

div.p: As we work through this difficult situation, please know that:

li.p: We will continue to provide grab-and-go meals for all children under 18 during the extended closure.
Our facilities will remain closed to students during the extended closure.
Our goal is to deliver supplemental education and learning supports to students to the extent practical through independent study and other appropriate options by April 1st.
Our custodians will deep clean all surfaces in our schools, closing off rooms when complete, to ensure they remain disinfected for when students and staff return.

div.p: While our students are away from school, please help them understand the importance of this national health emergency by encouraging social distancing, good hand-washing skills, avoiding people who are sick, and covering their coughs and sneezes. Gatherings of more than 10 people are not recommended by the U.S. government at this time.
We appreciate your understanding as we navigate this challenging and quickly evolving situation. You can continue to find more information and resources at the following websites:

li.p: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: www.cdc.gov

div.p: We will continue to communicate updates to students, families and staff as additional information becomes available and more plans are put into place to manage this extended closure.
Thank you for your support and all you are doing to help stop the spread of this virus and protect our communities.

Glendale Families,<\/hatul>We understand that this is a difficult time for our students and their families. Our top priority right now remains the safety and health of our students and staff. We are also working closely with the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) as we work to support our graduating seniors, for our students return to school, and to provide continuity of learning to the fullest extent possible. We continue to look for additional guidance from ODE on how to equitably deliver instruction to all students during this extended closure.<\/hatul>As you have been made aware, due to the COVID-19 public health concerns, Governor Brown recently announced an extension of Oregon’s statewide school closure through April 28, 2020. Governor Brown’s Executive Order directs schools across the State of Oregon to:<\/hatul>\n\t
\n\tRemain closed through Tuesday, April 28, 2020. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tDeliver supplemental education and learning supports to students, to the extent practical, through independent study and other appropriate options.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tProvide meals for students during this closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tProvide for supplemental services and emergency management services, including but not limited to, the provision of child care for first responders, emergency workers, health care professionals, and other individuals, consistent with any guidance and requirements provided by the Oregon Department of Education. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n<\/ol> <\/hatul>As we work through this difficult situation, please know that:<\/hatul>\n\t
\n\tWe will continue to provide grab-and-go meals for all children under 18 during the extended closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur facilities will remain closed to students during the extended closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur goal is to deliver supplemental education and learning supports to students to the extent practical through independent study and other appropriate options by April 1st.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur custodians will deep clean all surfaces in our schools, closing off rooms when complete, to ensure they remain disinfected for when students and staff return. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n<\/ul> <\/hatul>While our students are away from school, please help them understand the importance of this national health emergency by encouraging social distancing, good hand-washing skills, avoiding people who are sick, and covering their coughs and sneezes. Gatherings of more than 10 people are not recommended by the U.S. government at this time.<\/hatul>We appreciate your understanding as we navigate this challenging and quickly evolving situation. You can continue to find more information and resources at the following websites:<\/hatul>\n\t
\n\tDouglas Public Health Network: www.douglaspublichealthnetwork.org<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOregon Health Authority: www.oregon.gov\/oha<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tCenters for Disease Control and Prevention: www.cdc.gov<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tDouglas Education Service District: www.douglasesd.k12.or.us\/covid-19-information-and-resources<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n<\/ul>We will continue to communicate updates to students, families and staff as additional information becomes available and more plans are put into place to manage this extended closure.<\/hatul>Thank you for your support and all you are doing to help stop the spread of this virus and protect our communities.<\/hatul>David Hanson<\/hatul>Superintendent<\/hatul>Glendale School District<\/hatul> <\/hatul>","links":[],"imageList":[],"videoList":[],"refMap":{}},"title":"COVID-19 Closure","subPosts":[],"tags":[],"categoryIds":["156287c3d82165e138edad","156287e7448f91e379bf3c","156287c972017baaf75c89","156287c76691b15491abf2"],"date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2020-03-30T15:03:27.352Z"},"scheduled":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z"},"featured":true,"draft":false,"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"Dear Glendale Families,<\/hatul>We understand that this is a difficult time for our students and their families. Retrieval","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2020-04-28T15:37:31.249Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"Good afternoon,<\/hatul>This message is to inform you that Glendale High School students will be allowed on campus to pick up their belongings out of their lockers this upcoming Wednesday and Thursday 4\/29 and 4\/30. Strict social distancing protocols will be enforced, limited numbers of students will be allowed in the building during the same time and bags will be provided for students who need them while emptying their lockers’ contents. There will be collection bins available for text\/library books not being utilized during Q4 distance learning, and the remaining text\/library books being used by students during Q4 distance learning will be collected at the end of the school year. Students will be allowed to empty their PE\/Athletic lockers too.<\/hatul>In order to avoid too many students on campus at the same time, 9th\/10th grade students are being asked to empty their lockers between 9:00am and 12:00pm and 11th\/12th grade students are being asked to arrive between 12:00pm and 3:00pm. Students who are unable to participate in the locker clean out this week, may call the school office @ (541) 832-1801 and make arrangements. Lockers that aren’t emptied this week, will be emptied, bagged and labeled by custodial staff next week before cleaning\/sanitizing all lockers. Current GHS students are eligible to participate in the locker clean out. Thank you for your time and support…GO PIRATES!<\/hatul>Sheila, can you use this information to make a condensed version that you think will be ok for IRIS? Access to this feed may be obtained via link located at the district website www.glendale.k12.or.us.<\/span><\/hatul>Public comment will be taken in written format by contacting the district at communityquestions@glendale.k12.or.us. Comments received prior to 5:00 p.m. on May 5, 2020 will be read during the public comment section of the meeting on May 6, 2020. <\/span><\/hatul>A copy of the budget document will be available for inspection or obtained via link located on district website at www.glendale.k12.or.us. This means we will have a bus at your normal pickup location 2 hours later than normal in the morning routes. Busses will drop off breakfasts and lunches to all children ages 0 to 18. This will happen Monday through Thursday for the duration of this school closure. <\/hatul>For students that walk, Glendale School District will be serving breakfast and lunch from Glendale Elementary. Again, this will occur Monday through Thursday and will operate from 11:15 am to 12:30 pm. Families will need to come to the gym of Glendale Elementary. Please use the side entrance and enter through the front double doors of the gym to get food and we are asking families to exit through the rear gym doors. This will maintain social distancing protocols. <\/hatul>On Wednesday’s we will have instructional materials for students. These materials will be on bus routes and at Glendale Elementary to be picked up with food at the same times. These packets are to be done at home, and we are working to give students enriching material. These packets are not to be returned to school at this time. <\/hatul>At both schools (Glendale High School and Glendale Elem\/ Jr. High) we are working to have the offices staffed for phone calls from 9:00 am to 3:30 pm. Families can call the school to leave a message and we will get it to the teacher. Please be patient. You can always email teachers! For staff directories please visit: www.glendale.k12.or.us<\/hatul>Please remember the buildings are closed and parents and\/or students are not to enter, except in the gym through a confirmed entrance and exit. <\/hatul>This storm will pass and, we are thankful to be on this Pirate Ship, at this time, with this community! \nProposed General Obligation Bond Levy - May 2020
\nProposed G.O. BOND Q&A<\/hatul>1. Question<\/span>: Why was the bond measure referred to voters?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: The school board is proposing projects that would address safety and security issues that currently exist on the High School and Elementary campuses. This includes aging HVAC, communications, fire suppression and electrical systems, and the gymnasium floor. The buildings were constructed in the late 1970s, and are more than 40 years old.<\/hatul> These issues can provide unsafe environments for our students and staff. The campus and facilities were not designed with security in mind, since this issue was not a consideration in the 1970s. The current campus and facilities were designed to be open and welcoming to the students and community. This design provides many points of access and creates a physical environment that is very difficult to monitor for safety or even lock down effectively.<\/hatul> <\/hatul> The district set aside 7.5% of its 2019-20 budget for maintenance, or a total of $698,000. Addressing these maintenance projects through the bond levy would reduce the amount the district would need to budget for maintenance in the future.<\/hatul> If the levy passes, the projects the Glendale School Board has identified would improve safety and security for students, teachers, and staff, and energy efficiency throughout the district. Generally speaking, the projects would be meant to
\nextend the life of the district’s resources.<\/hatul>2. Question<\/span>: What are the proposed projects?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: If the levy passes, the projects identified by the Glendale School Board are:<\/hatul>• Installing new, energy efficient windows in all buildings
\n• Installing new HVAC systems and ductwork in all buildings
\n• Constructing secure entryways at both the High School and Elementary School
\n• Improve communications systems between buildings for safety
\n• Repair outdated electrical systems and fire suppression systems with its buildings
\n• Replace the gymnasium floor
\nIf passed, the current tax rate would not change. If the levy is not passed, the tax would not continue and the above projects would not be completed.<\/hatul>3. Question<\/span>: What dollar amount is proposed for the G.O. Bond?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: If the measure passes, the actual G.O. Bond amount would be $1.8 million.
\nGlendale School District Proposed General Obligation Bond Levy - May 2020<\/hatul>4. Question<\/span>: If passed, how many years would the G.O. Bond be in place before it matures?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: The current proposal is based on a 20-year bond maturity timeline.<\/hatul>5. Question<\/span>: When does the current Bond Levy end and when would the proposed Bond Levy begin?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: Taxpayers in the Glendale School District are currently paying $0.47 per $1,000 of assessed value. The current G.O. Bond matures in 2020. If passed, the proposed improvement bond would go into effect in January of 2021 as the existing bond matures and maintain the same estimated rate. If passed, the current tax rate would not change. If the levy is not passed, the tax would not continue.<\/hatul>6. Question<\/span>: How would the proposed G.O. Bond effect the current tax rate that provides the funding for the maturing G.O. Bond.<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: The Glendale School Board determined the G.O. Bond amount based on the amount required to make the needed improvements to the schools, without causing an increase to the current tax rate. The current average tax rate is $0.47 per $1,000 of assessed value.<\/hatul>• The board proposes borrowing no more funds than would pay for improvements and the proposal would maintain the current tax rate of an estimated $0.47 per thousand dollars assessed.
\n• The board also proposes to keep the length of the proposed bond to 20 years.<\/hatul>If passed, the current tax rate would not change. If the levy is not passed, the tax would not continue.<\/hatul>7. Question<\/span>: Why were these projects proposed? What about the Career Technical Education (CTE)\/vocational program
\nfacilities?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: The state of Oregon is helping school districts fund CTE program improvements through Measure 98, which was approved by voters in 2016. The Glendale School district is currently in the process of using Measure 98 funding to improve CTE programs. Those funds have allowed Glendale to join the south Douglas county consortium to create a manufacturing program, add three new computer classes, purchase Chromebooks for students, add a graduation coach in 2019, and
\npurchase two vehicles for ag and manufacturing student transportation. Because of Measure 98 funding, the Glendale School District can use bond levy revenue to address other priorities.<\/hatul>8. Question<\/span>: How much does the current school bond levy cost taxpayers? How much more would it cost if the proposed bond levy were to pass?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: Taxpayers inside the Glendale School District have been paying an average of an estimated $0.47 per $1,000 of assessed value on a bond levy approved in 2000. The current bond levy expires in December of 2020. If passed, the rate would remain at an estimated $0.47 per $1,000 of assessed value beginning in January of 2021.<\/hatul>For example, a property owner inside the Glendale School District with an assessed value of $100,000 would pay a total of approximately $47 per year, or $3.91 per month, if the levy passes. A property owner inside the Glendale School District with an assessed value of $200,<\/hatul>000 would pay a total of approximately $94 per year, or $7.84 per month, if the levy passes. If the levy is not passed, the tax would not go into effect and the projects would not be completed.<\/hatul>9. Question<\/span>: Can bond levy funds be used to provide pay raises for School Administrators or other school employees?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: State law prevents the bond funds from being spent on salaries for teachers or administrators.<\/hatul>10. Question<\/span>: What is a General Obligation Bond (G.O. Bond)?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: G.O. Bonds are tax levies that, if passed by voters, would allow school districts, community colleges, cities, and counties to fund capital improvement projects that otherwise might not be completed with general fund dollars. G.O. Bonds decided in May or November elections are approved or failed on a majority vote. ‘Double majority’ approval is not necessary in Primary or General Elections in the state of Oregon.
\n Content Retrieval","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2020-04-28T15:37:31.249Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"Good afternoon,<\/hatul>This message is to inform you that Glendale High School students will be allowed on campus to pick up their belongings out of their lockers this upcoming Wednesday and Thursday 4\/29 and 4\/30. Strict social distancing protocols will be enforced, limited numbers of students will be allowed in the building during the same time and bags will be provided for students who need them while emptying their lockers’ contents. There will be collection bins available for text\/library books not being utilized during Q4 distance learning, and the remaining text\/library books being used by students during Q4 distance learning will be collected at the end of the school year. Students will be allowed to empty their PE\/Athletic lockers too.<\/hatul>In order to avoid too many students on campus at the same time, 9th\/10th grade students are being asked to empty their lockers between 9:00am and 12:00pm and 11th\/12th grade students are being asked to arrive between 12:00pm and 3:00pm. Students who are unable to participate in the locker clean out this week, may call the school office @ (541) 832-1801 and make arrangements. Lockers that aren’t emptied this week, will be emptied, bagged and labeled by custodial staff next week before cleaning\/sanitizing all lockers. Current GHS students are eligible to participate in the locker clean out. Thank you for your time and support…GO PIRATES!<\/hatul>Sheila, can you use this information to make a condensed version that you think will be ok for IRIS? Please submit to me for final approval before we send out the IRIS alert.<\/hatul>Thanks!<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":"","imageSrc":"https:\/\/static.parastorage.com\/services\/santa-resources\/resources\/viewer\/video\/not-found.png"},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Locker Content Retrieval","_iid":"5ea84d8d71a6b31fadd35be1","_hash":"f16ca5d6a9799d9ebb35154ed02747f8","_createdAt":"2020-04-28T15:36:45.073Z","_updatedAt":"2020-04-28T15:37:31.715Z","permalink":"2020\/04\/28\/Locker-Content-Retrieval","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[],"httpsOnPublish":false},"5e9dc092ee4bd31955f469db":{"_type":"PhotoPost","title":"Budget Committee Meeting","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2020-04-20T15:33:17.234Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"NOTICE OF BUDGET COMMITTEE MEETING<\/span><\/hatul>A public meeting of the Budget Committee of the Glendale School District #77, Douglas County, State of Oregon, will be held on May 6, 2020 at 6:00 p.m. The purpose of the meeting is to receive the budget message and to receive comment from the public on the budget. <\/span><\/hatul>In response to the current health emergency resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic, the District facilities are currently closed to the public and meetings are being held electronically. Access to this feed may be obtained via link located at the district website www.glendale.k12.or.us.<\/span><\/hatul>Public comment will be taken in written format by contacting the district at communityquestions@glendale.k12.or.us. Comments received prior to 5:00 p.m. on May 5, 2020 will be read during the public comment section of the meeting on May 6, 2020. <\/span><\/hatul>A copy of the budget document will be available for inspection or obtained via link located on district website at www.glendale.k12.or.us. If additional meetings for deliberation are required, they will be scheduled at this meeting.<\/span><\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"photo","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":"","imageSrc":"https:\/\/static.parastorage.com\/services\/santa-resources\/resources\/viewer\/video\/not-found.png"},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"31ce53_60bf82f995ab4e8886e093cb10b94190~mv2.jpg","width":1707,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Budget Committee Meeting","_iid":"5e9dc092ee4bd31955f469db","_hash":"fc39e7bf8fab1f2cc9b65ab74ecba949","_createdAt":"2020-04-20T15:32:34.377Z","_updatedAt":"2020-04-20T15:33:36.544Z","permalink":"2020\/04\/20\/Budget-Committee-Meeting","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[],"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"31ce53_60bf82f995ab4e8886e093cb10b94190~mv2.jpg","width":1707,"height":960},"httpsOnPublish":false},"5e8b619330dc90032b33230f":{"_type":"PhotoPost","title":"Updated Letter From Principal Endicott","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2020-04-06T17:08:29.869Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"Glendale Elementary\/Jr. High<\/hatul>Dan Endicott, Principal<\/hatul>P.O. Box E, Glendale, OR 97442<\/hatul>www.glendale.k12.or.us<\/hatul>PH #(541) 832-1701 FAX #(541) 832-2158<\/hatul>3\/30\/2020<\/hatul>To the Families of Glendale School District,<\/hatul>With warmest regards in this unprecedented time! I am writing to give information on what will start on Wednesday 4\/1\/2020.<\/hatul>Glendale School District will have our bus routes operating on a two-hour delay. This means we will have a bus at your normal pickup location 2 hours later than normal in the morning routes. Busses will drop off breakfasts and lunches to all children ages 0 to 18. This will happen Monday through Thursday for the duration of this school closure. <\/hatul>For students that walk, Glendale School District will be serving breakfast and lunch from Glendale Elementary. Again, this will occur Monday through Thursday and will operate from 11:15 am to 12:30 pm. Families will need to come to the gym of Glendale Elementary. Please use the side entrance and enter through the front double doors of the gym to get food and we are asking families to exit through the rear gym doors. This will maintain social distancing protocols. <\/hatul>On Wednesday’s we will have instructional materials for students. These materials will be on bus routes and at Glendale Elementary to be picked up with food at the same times. These packets are to be done at home, and we are working to give students enriching material. These packets are not to be returned to school at this time. <\/hatul>At both schools (Glendale High School and Glendale Elem\/ Jr. High) we are working to have the offices staffed for phone calls from 9:00 am to 3:30 pm. Families can call the school to leave a message and we will get it to the teacher. Please be patient. You can always email teachers! For staff directories please visit: www.glendale.k12.or.us<\/hatul>Please remember the buildings are closed and parents and\/or students are not to enter, except in the gym through a confirmed entrance and exit. <\/hatul>This storm will pass and, we are thankful to be on this Pirate Ship, at this time, with this community! Our top priority right now remains the safety and health of our students and staff. We are also working closely with the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) as we work to support our graduating seniors, for our students return to school, and to provide continuity of learning to the fullest extent possible. We continue to look for additional guidance from ODE on how to equitably deliver instruction to all students during this extended closure.<\/hatul>As you have been made aware, due to the COVID-19 public health concerns, Governor Brown recently announced an extension of Oregon’s statewide school closure through April 28, 2020. Governor Brown’s Executive Order directs schools across the State of Oregon to:<\/hatul>\n\t
\n\tRemain closed through Tuesday, April 28, 2020. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tDeliver supplemental education and learning supports to students, to the extent practical, through independent study and other appropriate options.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tProvide meals for students during this closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tProvide for supplemental services and emergency management services, including but not limited to, the provision of child care for first responders, emergency workers, health care professionals, and other individuals, consistent with any guidance and requirements provided by the Oregon Department of Education. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n<\/ol> <\/hatul>As we work through this difficult situation, please know that:<\/hatul>\n\t
\n\tWe will continue to provide grab-and-go meals for all children under 18 during the extended closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur facilities will remain closed to students during the extended closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur goal is to deliver supplemental education and learning supports to students to the extent practical through independent study and other appropriate options by April 1st.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur custodians will deep clean all surfaces in our schools, closing off rooms when complete, to ensure they remain disinfected for when students and staff return. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n<\/ul> <\/hatul>While our students are away from school, please help them understand the importance of this national health emergency by encouraging social distancing, good hand-washing skills, avoiding people who are sick, and covering their coughs and sneezes. Gatherings of more than 10 people are not recommended by the U.S. government at this time.<\/hatul>We appreciate your understanding as we navigate this challenging and quickly evolving situation. You can continue to find more information and resources at the following websites:<\/hatul>\n\t
\n\tDouglas Public Health Network: www.douglaspublichealthnetwork.org<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOregon Health Authority: www.oregon.gov\/oha<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tCenters for Disease Control and Prevention: www.cdc.gov<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tDouglas Education Service District: www.douglasesd.k12.or.us\/covid-19-information-and-resources<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n<\/ul>We will continue to communicate updates to students, families and staff as additional information becomes available and more plans are put into place to manage this extended closure.<\/hatul>Thank you for your support and all you are doing to help stop the spread of this virus and protect our communities.<\/hatul>David Hanson<\/hatul>Superintendent<\/hatul>Glendale School District<\/hatul> <\/hatul>","links":[],"imageList":[],"videoList":[],"refMap":{}},"title":"COVID-19 Closure","subPosts":[],"tags":[],"categoryIds":["156287c3d82165e138edad","156287e7448f91e379bf3c","156287c972017baaf75c89","156287c76691b15491abf2"],"date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2020-03-30T15:03:27.352Z"},"scheduled":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z"},"featured":true,"draft":false,"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"Dear Glendale Families,<\/hatul>We understand that this is a difficult time for our students and their families. We continue to look for additional guidance from ODE on how to equitably deliver instruction to all students during this extended closure.<\/hatul>As you have been made aware, due to the COVID-19 public health concerns, Governor Brown recently announced an extension of Oregon’s statewide school closure through April 28, 2020. Governor Brown’s Executive Order directs schools across the State of Oregon to:<\/hatul>\n\t
\n\tRemain closed through Tuesday, April 28, 2020. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tDeliver supplemental education and learning supports to students, to the extent practical, through independent study and other appropriate options.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tProvide meals for students during this closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tProvide for supplemental services and emergency management services, including but not limited to, the provision of child care for first responders, emergency workers, health care professionals, and other individuals, consistent with any guidance and requirements provided by the Oregon Department of Education. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n<\/ol>As we work through this difficult situation, please know that:<\/hatul>\n\t
\n\tWe will continue to provide grab-and-go meals for all children under 18 during the extended closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur facilities will remain closed to students during the extended closure.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur goal is to deliver supplemental education and learning supports to students to the extent practical through independent study and other appropriate options by April 1st.<\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n\t
\n\tOur custodians will deep clean all surfaces in our schools, closing off rooms when complete, to ensure they remain disinfected for when students and staff return. <\/hatul>\n\t<\/li>\n<\/ul>While our students are away from school, please help them understand the importance of this national health emergency by encouraging social distancing, good hand-washing skills, avoiding people who are sick, and covering their coughs and sneezes. Gatherings of more than 10 people are not recommended by the U.S. government at this time.<\/hatul>We appreciate your understanding as we navigate this challenging and quickly evolving situation. \nProposed General Obligation Bond Levy - May 2020
\nProposed G.O. BOND Q&A<\/hatul>1. Question<\/span>: Why was the bond measure referred to voters?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: The school board is proposing projects that would address safety and security issues that currently exist on the High School and Elementary campuses. This includes aging HVAC, communications, fire suppression and electrical systems, and the gymnasium floor. The buildings were constructed in the late 1970s, and are more than 40 years old.<\/hatul> These issues can provide unsafe environments for our students and staff. The campus and facilities were not designed with security in mind, since this issue was not a consideration in the 1970s. The current campus and facilities were designed to be open and welcoming to the students and community. This design provides many points of access and creates a physical environment that is very difficult to monitor for safety or even lock down effectively.<\/hatul> <\/hatul> The district set aside 7.5% of its 2019-20 budget for maintenance, or a total of $698,000. Addressing these maintenance projects through the bond levy would reduce the amount the district would need to budget for maintenance in the future.<\/hatul> If the levy passes, the projects the Glendale School Board has identified would improve safety and security for students, teachers, and staff, and energy efficiency throughout the district. Generally speaking, the projects would be meant to
\nextend the life of the district’s resources.<\/hatul>2. Question<\/span>: What are the proposed projects?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: If the levy passes, the projects identified by the Glendale School Board are:<\/hatul>• Installing new, energy efficient windows in all buildings
\n• Installing new HVAC systems and ductwork in all buildings
\n• Constructing secure entryways at both the High School and Elementary School
\n• Improve communications systems between buildings for safety
\n• Repair outdated electrical systems and fire suppression systems with its buildings
\n• Replace the gymnasium floor
\nIf passed, the current tax rate would not change. If the levy is not passed, the tax would not continue and the above projects would not be completed.<\/hatul>3. Question<\/span>: What dollar amount is proposed for the G.O. Bond?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: If the measure passes, the actual G.O. Bond amount would be $1.8 million.
\nGlendale School District Proposed General Obligation Bond Levy - May 2020<\/hatul>4. Question<\/span>: If passed, how many years would the G.O. Bond be in place before it matures?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: The current proposal is based on a 20-year bond maturity timeline.<\/hatul>5. Question<\/span>: When does the current Bond Levy end and when would the proposed Bond Levy begin?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: Taxpayers in the Glendale School District are currently paying $0.47 per $1,000 of assessed value. The current G.O. Bond matures in 2020. If passed, the proposed improvement bond would go into effect in January of 2021 as the existing bond matures and maintain the same estimated rate. If passed, the current tax rate would not change. If the levy is not passed, the tax would not continue.<\/hatul>6. Question<\/span>: How would the proposed G.O. Bond effect the current tax rate that provides the funding for the maturing G.O. Bond.<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: The Glendale School Board determined the G.O. Bond amount based on the amount required to make the needed improvements to the schools, without causing an increase to the current tax rate. The current average tax rate is $0.47 per $1,000 of assessed value.<\/hatul>• The board proposes borrowing no more funds than would pay for improvements and the proposal would maintain the current tax rate of an estimated $0.47 per thousand dollars assessed.
\n• The board also proposes to keep the length of the proposed bond to 20 years.<\/hatul>If passed, the current tax rate would not change. If the levy is not passed, the tax would not continue.<\/hatul>7. Question<\/span>: Why were these projects proposed? What about the Career Technical Education (CTE)\/vocational program
\nfacilities?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: The state of Oregon is helping school districts fund CTE program improvements through Measure 98, which was approved by voters in 2016. The Glendale School district is currently in the process of using Measure 98 funding to improve CTE programs. Those funds have allowed Glendale to join the south Douglas county consortium to create a manufacturing program, add three new computer classes, purchase Chromebooks for students, add a graduation coach in 2019, and
\npurchase two vehicles for ag and manufacturing student transportation. Because of Measure 98 funding, the Glendale School District can use bond levy revenue to address other priorities.<\/hatul>8. Question<\/span>: How much does the current school bond levy cost taxpayers? How much more would it cost if the proposed bond levy were to pass?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: Taxpayers inside the Glendale School District have been paying an average of an estimated $0.47 per $1,000 of assessed value on a bond levy approved in 2000. The current bond levy expires in December of 2020. If passed, the rate would remain at an estimated $0.47 per $1,000 of assessed value beginning in January of 2021.<\/hatul>For example, a property owner inside the Glendale School District with an assessed value of $100,000 would pay a total of approximately $47 per year, or $3.91 per month, if the levy passes. A property owner inside the Glendale School District with an assessed value of $200,<\/hatul>000 would pay a total of approximately $94 per year, or $7.84 per month, if the levy passes. If the levy is not passed, the tax would not go into effect and the projects would not be completed.<\/hatul>9. Question<\/span>: Can bond levy funds be used to provide pay raises for School Administrators or other school employees?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: State law prevents the bond funds from being spent on salaries for teachers or administrators.<\/hatul>10. Question<\/span>: What is a General Obligation Bond (G.O. Bond)?<\/hatul>Answer<\/span>: G.O. Bonds are tax levies that, if passed by voters, would allow school districts, community colleges, cities, and counties to fund capital improvement projects that otherwise might not be completed with general fund dollars. G.O. Bonds decided in May or November elections are approved or failed on a majority vote. ‘Double majority’ approval is not necessary in Primary or General Elections in the state of Oregon.
\n
